text:
I couldn't finish watching this movie. I thought the story-telling was abysmal and the plot was filled with plot holes. I can't stand plot holes. I found myself going online in the middle of the movie to ask basic questions about the plot and what happened to certain characters. Huge Red Flags. 

Is this one of those movies where the producer and the studio comes in and changes everything at the last minute, cause maybe that would explain the pacing, the lack of a concise plot, the unanswered questions, the terrible ambiguity...


Spoiler: After the fire, why didn't the main character look for his wife and kids in town? Why didn't he check with her family, with the police, with anyone? He didn't post flyers, he didn't do anything except sleep at the cabin. He didn't check the hospitals, the morgue....he didn't do anything to look for his family. How about the church? Then the narrator tells us that years went by. It's just bad story telling.

Reminds me of Homer from the Simpsons. "Marge! I can't find the remote. I've tried nothing, and I'm all out of ideas." 

Also, the scene where he walks into the forest fire really threw me out of the immersion. So fake. That's not how fires and oxygen works, but ok guys. Maybe the directors should have done some research on fires, forest fires, oxygen, etc... Maybe they could have talked to some fire fighters.... anyways. 

Boring movie, with no plot, except plot armor, with terrible vague story telling that made me take my phone out to ask A.I. what is happening.

“Train Dreams” 2025

Strange dreams was a movie set back in the early 1900s I don’t know the western part of The US. A time where people had to go far away from your home to find work. So this story centers around a man and his family trying to raise a family in an era where hard work and scarcity of money were the norm. This particular story centered around a man who traveled far and wide to find work as a lumberjack. A profession that was not for the faint of heart as It was a very dangerous occupation. This is when railroads were starting to be built and bridges were made to connect cities. This was the story from the perspective of one lumberjack and his family and the hardships that faced them. Pretty good film although not a lot of action more like a movie biography in a way of early history in America. But I gave this film an 8 out of 10 stars. It probably really depicted the Life and Times of early 1900s in western America.

If you are over 65 or have even questioned whether you have fulfilled your life's dreams ... don't watch it is SOOOO depressing. Well made (except for some amateurish AI in the beginning) and nicely acted but ...
"The first half of the movie was excellent, but then it got lame to the point where I wouldn’t recommend it to anyone — and that’s just the truth."

He didn’t know at the time that these years would be the ones he missed the most. We hurt for Robert, we root for him from the start of the tale, but we hurt for him throughout. The beauty of the land, the colour of memory. It’s as powerful as There Will Be Blood, it’s as painful as Requiem for a dream, it’s pure genius. It will win many Oscar’s but who cares. It’s a truly beautiful film.
Incredible film. From start to finish simply brilliant.

I'm still trying to figure out why this film was called "Train Dreams". Aside from the underlying history of Western expansion, this film wasn't about trains. In fact, the only thing really interesting about the film was the tapestry of the passage of time during a lifetime that saw some incredible changes across cultural, social, and technological advances. I didn't find the film deep or even particularily emotional, rather I found it strangely disconnected ... which may have been a direct result of the overall lack of dialogue.

If I can save one person from seeing this movie, my life will have had more purpose than its plot.   Plodding pathos and One Big Tragedy, unleavened by any hints of wisdom or redemption, surprisingly makes for bad storytelling.   Honestly, who is the intended audience for this film?  Nihilistic Loggers of America?  Artsy eastern Oregon?  My time would have been better spent reading obituaries.

te sumerges en la vida de Mr Grainier, gran actuación por parte de Joel Edgerton, te hace sentir y comprender lo que era la vida en los bosques del Pacific Northwest in the early 20th Century dejándonos claro que el tiempo no deja de avanzar y que todo sigue evolucionando mientras intentamos comprender que nuestro rol en este planeta es simplemente vivir.
It was a beautiful story, well filmed and Joel Edgerton and the entire cast was great.

One of the most visually beautiful and emotionally moving films I've seen in several years. The chemistry between Edgerton and Jones is amazing, and I loved watching William Macy and John Diehl. Edgerton is only about 5" taller than Jones, yet he seems visually, physically to be a bear of a man to her small, slender fawn of a woman. Kerry Condon is remarkable in a smaller role, and I thought for a while that she and Edgerton would develop an intimate relationship, especially when they are up on the fire tower, but then I realize he's meant to be alone with his memories and faint hope.
Beautiful movie, profound and powerful and poetic.

I agree with the reviewers who found this movie disappointing.  The plot of the movie was disjoint.  It used narration to try to tie the episodes of the story together, but the narration did not achieve that end.  It was too self-consciously literary, and therefore somewhat pretentious.  The minor characters were not that well defined, so the plot did not hold together well after the death of Robert's wife and child.  The movie was too self-consciously arty to keep me invested in the story of Robert's life.

Beautiful, at times painful. A simple yet powerful story about an everyday couple living through extraordinary times.
There is so much wisdom in the dialogues, a quiet meditation on life and its small nuances.
If you enjoy European films and stories that stay with you, this is a must-watch..

Soulful and beautiful story of a good everyman who works with his hands to reshape his life and the Pacific NW  with perseverance and integrity through heartfelt moments of love and agonizing loss. Touching and tender performances by Joel Edgerton should definitely get him a nomination for an oscar. For me, this movie is a moving piece of art that is a stark contrast to our current times and culture which is so dependent on technology and progress fueled by greed and a materialism.  I believe this movie will resonate with most people's sense of what makes life beautiful and meaningful.

Sometimes the movie is fantastic and sometimes it feels it is trying so hard to be meaningful, poignant and cinematic that it instead feels cliche and over the top. The narration feels to be part of the problem, "he was one with the meaningfulness of the time and yet he had the understanding of a wistful lake who could not understand it's own meaningless in a field full of trees that do not worry nor...." you get the idea.
Visually stunning with engaging camera work. However the story is unrelentingly depressing and the narration is too distracting. Can recommend it.

So many reviews, professional-whatever that is-and ordinary folks, express appreciation for the acting, the beauty of the look and the, uh, I don’t know. The ordinary story of, for his time and experience, an ordinary man dealing with not at all unique challenges of the era. I can’t find the extra ordinary in this ordinary.
Beautiful homage to the men and women who built contemporary America.  Gorgeous soundtrack by Dessner.  Unmissable.

Despite its slow pace and tranquil music, the story of a railway worker has something that captivates us and makes us empathise with the main character. Of course, the final act leaves you feeling as if you have lost a friend.
